messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
> Sent: Saturday, June 26, 2004 5:07 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Control test order in base test case hierarchy.
>
> Ray Tayek wrote:
>
> > Suite.addTest(SuperClass.suite()) seems to dtrt, but it seems that you
> > *must* roll up up your tests in the subclass i.e. in the supbclass, you
> > must: suite.addTest(SubClassTestCase("nameOfTestInSuperClass"));
>
> Ah, yes. I may have misspoke (miswritten) earlier. Remember
> that classes do not inherit class-level methods, like suite(). Could that
> be related to your problem?

I was not clear, the tests get run when you roll 'em up in the superclass
test case, but they *are* instances of that super class (not the sub class).
And I was supplying different flavours of a test fixture (as well as testing
different sublcasses) to the super class test case by overriding a
getTestObject() in the super class test case that normally returned null.
Once I rolled up the tests in the sub class test case, the correct test
fixture was used by the test methods in the super class. This works fine.

But it is a bit ugly/complicated, since I have guards in some of my tests in
the super test case that check for a null test fixture as well as test for
whether I an testing a subclass or not. The idea was to have a test case
hierarchy that mirrored the class hierarchy that was being tested. This has
having common (for the super class and all subclasses) tests there. So if
the mirrored class (of the super test base) is concrete the super test case
can roll up a concrete instance of his mirror and test that mirror. The
alternative is to have an abstract test case in between the two that just
has common stuff for the sub test cases. This of course breaks the mirror :(

thanks
